error.signature: Unable to connect to the server: dial tcp: lookup cluster.example.com: no such host
error.regex: Unable to connect to the server|cluster.*unreachable|connection refused.*6443|dial tcp.*timeout

verdict.summary: Cannot reach the Kubernetes API server. Kubeconfig may be wrong, credentials expired, or the cluster is down.

dead_ends.why_fails: The issue is connectivity or configuration, not the kubectl binary

workarounds.action: Verify kubeconfig points to the correct cluster API endpoint
workarounds.how:
kubectl config view --minify
# Check 'server' URL is correct and reachable:
curl -k https://<cluster-api-server>:6443/healthz
# Verify KUBECONFIG env var: echo $KUBECONFIG

workarounds.action: Merge or switch kubeconfig context to point to the correct cluster
workarounds.how:
# List available contexts:
kubectl config get-contexts

# Switch to the correct context:
kubectl config use-context my-cluster-context

# Merge another kubeconfig file:
export KUBECONFIG=~/.kube/config:~/new-cluster-config
kubectl config view --flatten > ~/.kube/config_merged
mv ~/.kube/config_merged ~/.kube/config

workarounds.action: Renew or refresh expired cluster credentials
workarounds.how:
# For EKS:
aws eks update-kubeconfig --name my-cluster --region us-east-1

# For GKE:
gcloud container clusters get-credentials my-cluster --zone us-central1-a

# For kubeadm clusters with expired certs:
kubeadm certs check-expiration
kubeadm certs renew all

# Restart kube-apiserver after cert renewal.

frequently_confused_with.distinction: cluster-unreachable means the API server cannot be reached at all; forbidden means you reached the API server but lack permissions.
